channel.title: MorningBrew as a feed
channel.description: This is a feed of recent MorningBrew articles published by Huginn

item.title: The Week Ahead: July 12
item.description: Bastille Day is on Wednesday. Economic data: The number to watch is Tuesday’s Consumer Price Index, which measures inflation.  Everything else: Angela Merkel is visiting the White House for what will likely be the final time as German chancellor.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: July 12
item.description: Fisherman Eric Richins described the water crisis at Lake Mead to the LA Times. (Scientific American) I didn’t realize it was this bad.  Quote: “I knew the drought was bad.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Musk Faces Legal Questions Over SolarCity Acquisition
item.description: As Reuters asks, “Does Elon Musk control Tesla Inc., or does Tesla control Elon Musk?” so how was this bad for Tesla shareholders exactly? Musk didn’t need much due diligence before buying SolarCity—after all, his cousins founded it in 2006 and Musk served as the chairman.  The detailsThe lawsuit alleges that Tesla’s acquisition of SolarCity reeked with conflicts of interest and that Musk failed to disclose some liquidity problems at SolarCity.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Branson in Space: Risky or Reckless?
item.description: His personal ambitions are intertwined with the company’s—this space flight was inevitable.    Micron shares fell more than 6% following the news of Appleton’s death. A 2011 study found that CEOs with licenses to pilot small aircraft (an activity 30x more dangerous than driving a car) are 40% more likely to make a corporate acquisition and 15% more likely to take on greater leverage. The company has completed more than 20 test flights, but the mission has been delayed by technical issues and a pilot died in a test flight in 2014. Bottom line: When Richard Branson decided to create a space company, it’s probably because he wanted to go to space.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Richard Branson’s Launch Preview
item.description: Branson will be onboard Virgin Galactic’s VSS Unity flight, nine days ahead of Jeff Bezos’s expected launch for Blue Origin on July 20.  When the ship reaches peak altitude, Branson and the three other passengers—all Virgin Galactic employees—will feel weightless.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Money Matters: How to Stay Patient When Saving?
item.description: What are some tips on being patient when saving money? You see where I’m headed, Zach. Become one of the first subscribers. Well, to be fair I had goals, but like you, I thought it’d take too long before I’d see results. Saving is like hitting the gym in that months and years may pass before you notice results, and consistency and persistence is the key.
item.author: Ryan Lasker

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: July 10
item.description: It no longer has any meaning or whatever. (New Yorker) Read: Great Jones cookware and the illusion of the millennial aesthetic. Streaming and everything, movies.  Quote: “Hollywood as we know it is irrelevant.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Crypto-Friendly Wyoming Officially Recognizes a DAO
item.description: To be specific, the Cowboy State announced that the American CryptoFed DAO is now an LLC. Wyoming became the first US state to officially recognize a Decentralized Autonomous Organization (DAO) this week, its latest step to becoming the country’s most crypto-friendly place to live.   What’s in it for Wyoming?
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Biden Signs Executive Order to Promote Fair Competition
item.description: So he signed a beefy executive order yesterday containing 72 measures meant to target big business and promote competition in the US economy. and more, “Here’s a guide to what I think,” reflects the Biden administration's focus on slowing corporate consolidation in order to help the US consumer.   The executive order mentions everything from shipping fees to over-the-counter hearing aids to banking mergers. Joe Biden is tired of other presidents getting all the “trustbuster” recognition in the history books.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Meme Battle: Homer Sleeping Peacefully
item.description: This week's challenge: You can find the new meme template here for next Sunday.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Make It Work: When Is the Right Time to Become a Manager?
item.description: But only you can want it. It’s not like anyone says, “I want to be a manager when I grow up!” Now, my boss wants to put me into a manager role.  Of course, while managing can be extremely rewarding, it certainly isn’t for everyone. It’s totally normal for you to feel nervous about becoming a manager. I don’t think I’m ready or qualified for the role. Ask Kate here. Something bothering you at work? Let us know what happens! But...
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Icebreakers With...Malcolm Gladwell
item.description: Should we trust the US News & World Report college rankings? Does that preparation always take 10,000 hours? If I did not have to sleep, I would sleep anyway. Sleep is literally my favorite thing to do. 10 years down the line, which activity will passengers in driverless cars do most frequently: work, sleep, chat, or something else? My zombies would be Canadian, like me. If you had to make your own zombie movie, what would your zombies be like? I mean, come on. And then ask yourself: Is that thing you remember so well measurable and quantifiable? I always run before dinner. When I finish a run I usually think only about food. When did you realize The Little Mermaid was not like other Disney movies?  This interview has been lightly edited and condensed for clarity. They would be unfailingly polite. And comfort the afflicted!” I would repeat the greatest of all journalism dictums: “Afflict the comfortable!
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: July 9
item.description: (Slate) Read: “Cat Person” and me. The automaker has donated $55,000 to 37 Republican objectors this year, according to the Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Fidji Simo, Facebook Exec, Will Replace Apoorva Mehta as CEO of Instacart
item.description: Simo spent the last decade building Facebook’s mobile and product teams, impressing Instacart’s Mehta. Simo will be responsible for maintaining that growth in the face of more competition, and ensuring the company sticks the landing to its upcoming IPO later this year.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: 10-Year Treasury Yield Plunges to Its Lowest Level since February
item.description: Because investors sell bonds when they think inflation is coming, the runup in bond prices means the worst of Wall Street's inflation concerns may be over. Why it matters: At the most basic level, the 10-year yield is a key indicator of investors’ confidence in future US economic growth.
item.author: Sherry Qin

item.title: Global Venture Funding Uses Momentum From 2021’s First Quarter to Hit Record Highs in Second Quarter
item.description: Startups globally raised a record $156 billion last quarter, per a new report from CB Insights. $1 out of every $5 raised globally last quarter went to the fintech industry, for a total of $33.7 billion. The number of new unicorns has grown 491% over last year. With Stripe and Klarna, fintech boasts two of the five most valuable unicorns in the world.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: July 9
item.description: (Slate) Read: “Cat Person” and me. The automaker has donated $55,000 to 37 Republican objectors this year, according to the Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: 10-Year Treasury Yield Plunges to Its Lowest Level since February
item.description: Because investors sell bonds when they think inflation is coming, the runup in bond prices means inflation has become old news. Why it matters: At the most basic level, the 10-year yield is a key indicator of investors’ confidence in the US economy.
item.author: Sherry Qin

item.title: Global Venture Funding Uses Momentum From 2021’s First Quarter to Hit Record Highs in Second Quarter
item.description: In all, Tiger locked down 81 deals last quarter. The number of new unicorns has grown 491% over last year. Startups globally raised a record $156 billion last quarter, per a new report from CB Insights. It’s “still by far the largest tech hub,” says CB Insights. With Stripe and Klarna on its side, fintech boasts two of the most valuable unicorns in the world. $1 out of every $5 raised globally last quarter went to the fintech industry,  for a total of $33.7 billion.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Fidji Simo, Facebook Exec, Will Replace Apoorva Mehta as CEO of Instacart
item.description: Simo spent the last decade building Facebook’s mobile and product teams, and did a pretty good job at it. Simo will be responsible for maintaining that growth in the face of more competition, and for ensuring the company sticks its landing in the public markets later this year.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Ever Given is Free (Again) From Suez Canal After Multimillion Dollar Payout
item.description: In the end, Ever Given’s owner and insurers paid the SCA an undisclosed amount—some Egyptian media reported $550 million and a “we’re sorry” tugboat—and the ship carrying goods worth hundreds of millions continued its much-delayed journey to the Netherlands.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: July 8
item.description: (The Range Report)  Read: Some misunderstandings around the Sha’Carri Richardson saga. Experts say the challenge is a Hail Mary, but either way Trump began to send fundraising emails off of it immediately.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: What's Behind the Oil Squabble in the Gulf?
item.description: The UAE wants to increase its own production by more than the Saudi plan allows for, so talks fell apart and oil prices hit a six-year high earlier this week.     Looking ahead... The UAE’s strategy: The country is envisioning a future with more renewable energy and stricter climate-focused policies.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Reliance on Office Space Leaves Downtowns’ Futures Unstable
item.description: A jump in remote/hybrid work post-Covid could threaten central business districts in places like Boston and San Francisco, where office space makes up 70%–80% of downtown real estate, per a new study from the NYT’s Upshot with CoStar.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: China Tightens Regulations On Its Tech Companies
item.description: The change would force companies classified under a certain corporate structure (known as the Variable Interest Entity model if you want to sound smart af) to seek the government’s approval before listing shares in the US or Hong Kong. Hong Kong could soon become the only place for non-Chinese investors to buy stakes in Chinese tech companies as regulators throttle firms listed in the US. When Didi decided to go public anyway last week, the government halted new app downloads and user signups in China.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: China Tightens Regulations On Its Tech Companies
item.description: Hong Kong could soon become the only place for non-Chinese investors to buy stakes in Chinese tech companies as regulators throttle firms listed in the US. The change would force companies classified under a certain corporate structure (known as the Variable Interest Entity model if you want to sound smart af) to seek the government’s approval before listing shares in the US or Hong Kong. all this could lead to a possible techxodus of up to $2 trillion worth of shares from US markets to China.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Reliance on Office Space Leaves Downtowns’ Futures Unstable
item.description: A jump in remote/hybrid work post-Covid could threaten central business districts in places like Boston and San Francisco, where office space makes up 70%–80% of downtown real estate, per new analysis from the NYT’s Upshot with CoStar.
item.author: Matty Merritt

The UAE’s strategy: The country is envisioning a future with more renewable energy and stricter climate-focused policies.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Employees in Iceland Start Working Four Days a Week
item.description: Both Spain and Japan are piloting a 32-hour work week over three years in response to changing perceptions of work during Covid.   Buffer, a social media software company, has let its 89 employees work four days a week since May 2020. Researchers found that a four-day week with the same pay improved workers’ well-being and productivity.
item.author: Sherry Qin

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: July 7
item.description: (The Guardian) Read: Is it time to give up caffeine? The disaster is starting to ripple across South Florida’s sizzling real estate sector.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Nextdoor Announces SPAC With Expected $4.3 Billion Valuation
item.description: Like other social media companies, it uses a mix of machine-learning tech and human moderators to supervise discussion. Big picture: As the company scales and goes public, it'll be under greater scrutiny from investors to address racism and other toxic behaviors that have already surfaced on the app.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Subway Overhauls Menu in a Bid to Win Back Consumers
item.description: While fast-food rivals enjoyed booming demand for contactless pickups during Covid, Subway missed out on that opportunity since fewer than one in 10 Subway stores had a drive-thru.  But not too much innovation.
item.author: Sherry Qin

item.title: Pentagon Cancels Controversial JEDI Contract in Favor of Multi-Vendor Model
item.description: The Pentagon is replacing JEDI with the Joint Warfighter Cloud Capability (JWCC) project and opening up the contract to multiple potential vendors including Amazon, Microsoft, Alphabet, and anyone else that can prove they’ve got the cloud computing chops to give the Defense Department an IT makeover. Cancel culture strikes again: The Pentagon said yesterday it’s scrapping its $10 billion JEDI cloud-computing contract with Microsoft and replacing it with another one that will require multiple vendors.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Employees in Iceland Start Working Four Days a Week
item.description: Researchers found that a four-day week with the same pay improved workers’ well-being and productivity.   Buffer, a social media software company, has let its 89 employees work four days a week since May 2020.
